slide.title: Cystogastrostomy: Metal stents or Plastic stents
slide.titleNormalized: cystogastrostomy: metal stents or plastic stents
slide.notes: Thank you for your kind introduction. Today, I’m going to present the title of cystogastrostomy with metal stents or plastic stents.
slide.notesNormalized: thank you for your kind introduction. today, i’m going to present the title of cystogastrostomy with metal stents or plastic stents.
slide.notesHtml: Thank you for your kind introduction. Today, I’m going to present the title of cystogastrostomy with metal stents or plastic stents.
slide.text:
Cystogastrostomy: Metal stents or Plastic stents Park Chang Hwan
Chonnam National University Medical School, Gwangju, Korea

slide.title: Pseudocysts
slide.notes: Pseudocysts are one of most common complications of acute and chronic pancreatitis. It’s incidence is from 10 to 26% in acute pancreatitis and from 20 to 40% in chronic pancreatitis.Pseudocysts are usually regressed spontaneously. But, symptomatic pseudocysts need treatment, Nowadays, endoscopic techniques can successfully treat most of symptomatic pseudocysts.
slide.notesNormalized: pseudocysts are one of most common complications of acute and chronic pancreatitis. it’s incidence is from 10 to 26% in acute pancreatitis and from 20 to 40% in chronic pancreatitis.pseudocysts are usually regressed spontaneously. but, symptomatic pseudocysts need treatment, nowadays, endoscopic techniques can successfully treat most of symptomatic pseudocysts.
slide.notesHtml: Pseudocysts are one of most common complications of acute and chronic pancreatitis. It’s incidence is from 10 to 26% in acute pancreatitis and from 20 to 40% in chronic pancreatitis.Pseudocysts are usually regressed spontaneously. But, symptomatic pseudocysts need treatment, Nowadays, endoscopic techniques can successfully treat most of symptomatic pseudocysts.
slide.text: Pseudocysts One of most common complications of acute/chronic pancreatitis Incidence;10-26%/20-40% in acute/chronic pancreatitis Endoscopic techniques can successfully treat symptomatic pseudocysts. Samuelson AL, et al. Endoscopic management of pancreatic pseudocysts. Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2012;41:47–62.

slide.title: Revised Atlanta Definition of Morphologic Features of Acute Pancreatitis, 2012
slide.titleNormalized: revised atlanta definition of morphologic features of acute pancreatitis, 2012
slide.notes: The 2012 revised Atlanta criteria classifies pancreatic fluid collections as acute or chronic, chronic fluid collections were subdivided into pseudocysts and walled-off pancreatic necrosis (WOPN). Pancreatic pseudocysts were defined as well-circumscribed, completely encapsulated fluid collections more than 4 weeks old; surrounded by a nonepithelial wall of fibrous or granulation tissue; homogeneous and without a nonliquid component; and arising as a consequence of acute pancreatitis, chronic pancreatitis, or pancreatic trauma with pancreatic ductal disruption.
slide.notesNormalized: the 2012 revised atlanta criteria classifies pancreatic fluid collections as acute or chronic, chronic fluid collections were subdivided into pseudocysts and walled-off pancreatic necrosis (wopn). pancreatic pseudocysts were defined as well-circumscribed, completely encapsulated fluid collections more than 4 weeks old; surrounded by a nonepithelial wall of fibrous or granulation tissue; homogeneous and without a nonliquid component; and arising as a consequence of acute pancreatitis, chronic pancreatitis, or pancreatic trauma with pancreatic ductal disruption.
slide.notesHtml: The 2012 revised Atlanta criteria classifies pancreatic fluid collections as acute or chronic, chronic fluid collections were subdivided into pseudocysts and walled-off pancreatic necrosis (WOPN). Pancreatic pseudocysts were defined as well-circumscribed, completely encapsulated fluid collections more than 4 weeks old; surrounded by a nonepithelial wall of fibrous or granulation tissue; homogeneous and without a nonliquid component; and arising as a consequence of acute pancreatitis, chronic pancreatitis, or pancreatic trauma with pancreatic ductal disruption.
slide.text: Revised Atlanta Definition of Morphologic Features of Acute Pancreatitis, 2012

slide.title: Acute interstitial oedematous pancreatitis
slide.notes: Pancreatic pseudocysts are diagnosed with CT criteria; first, well circumscribed, usually round or oval shape; second, homogeneous fluid density; 3rd, no non-liquid component ; 4th, well defined wall; that is, completely encapsulated.
slide.notesNormalized: pancreatic pseudocysts are diagnosed with ct criteria; first, well circumscribed, usually round or oval shape; second, homogeneous fluid density; 3rd, no non-liquid component ; 4th, well defined wall; that is, completely encapsulated.
slide.notesHtml: Pancreatic pseudocysts are diagnosed with CT criteria; first, well circumscribed, usually round or oval shape; second, homogeneous fluid density; 3rd, no non-liquid component ; 4th, well defined wall; that is, completely encapsulated.
slide.text: Copyright © BMJ Publishing Group Ltd & British Society of Gastroenterology. All rights reserved. Acute necrotising pancreatitis complicated by infected pancreatic necrosis. Acute interstitial oedematous pancreatitis.

slide.title: Symptomatic pseudocysts
slide.notes: In general, the indications for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage include persistent pain attributable to the fluid collection, gastric or duodenal obstruction, biliary obstruction, development of pancreatic ascites or pleural effusion, enlarging size on serial imaging, and signs of pseudocyst infection or bleeding.
slide.notesNormalized: in general, the indications for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage include persistent pain attributable to the fluid collection, gastric or duodenal obstruction, biliary obstruction, development of pancreatic ascites or pleural effusion, enlarging size on serial imaging, and signs of pseudocyst infection or bleeding.
slide.notesHtml: In general, the indications for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage include persistent pain attributable to the fluid collection, gastric or duodenal obstruction, biliary obstruction, development of pancreatic ascites or pleural effusion, enlarging size on serial imaging, and signs of pseudocyst infection or bleeding.
slide.text:
Symptomatic pseudocysts Persistent abdominal pain Gastric, duodenal, or biliary obstruction Pancreatic ascites/development of pleural effusion Enlarging size on serial abdominal imaging Pseudocyst infection Pseudocyst hemorrhage
Ge PS, et al. Pancreatic pseudocysts, Advances in endoscopic management . Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2016;45:9-27.

slide.title: Exclusion criteria for pseudocyst drainage
slide.notes: An important step before consideration of drainage is the exclusion of other cystic lesions, such as pancreatic cystic neoplasm. Pancreatic cystic neoplasm often appear morphologically similar to pseudocysts on cross-sectional imaging, and additional evaluation with endoscopic ultrasonography and fine-needle aspiration of the cyst fluid may be necessary before endoscopic drainage. Pancreatic pseudocysts and walled-off necrosis should also be differentiated from acute peripancreatic fluid collections and acute necrotic collections, both of which occur in the acute phase of pancreatitis or necrotizing pancreatitis. These collections have yet to develop an encapsulated, well-defined wall surrounding the fluid collection, and often resolve with expectant management
slide.notesNormalized: an important step before consideration of drainage is the exclusion of other cystic lesions, such as pancreatic cystic neoplasm. pancreatic cystic neoplasm often appear morphologically similar to pseudocysts on cross-sectional imaging, and additional evaluation with endoscopic ultrasonography and fine-needle aspiration of the cyst fluid may be necessary before endoscopic drainage. pancreatic pseudocysts and walled-off necrosis should also be differentiated from acute peripancreatic fluid collections and acute necrotic collections, both of which occur in the acute phase of pancreatitis or necrotizing pancreatitis. these collections have yet to develop an encapsulated, well-defined wall surrounding the fluid collection, and often resolve with expectant management
slide.notesHtml: An important step before consideration of drainage is the exclusion of other cystic lesions, such as pancreatic cystic neoplasm. Pancreatic cystic neoplasm often appear morphologically similar to pseudocysts on cross-sectional imaging, and additional evaluation with endoscopic ultrasonography and fine-needle aspiration of the cyst fluid may be necessary before endoscopic drainage. Pancreatic pseudocysts and walled-off necrosis should also be differentiated from acute peripancreatic fluid collections and acute necrotic collections, both of which occur in the acute phase of pancreatitis or necrotizing pancreatitis. These collections have yet to develop an encapsulated, well-defined wall surrounding the fluid collection, and often resolve with expectant management
slide.text:
Exclusion criteria for pseudocyst drainage Pancreatic cystic neoplasm Sterile acute peripancreatic fluid collections Sterile acute necrotic collections
Ge PS, et al. Pancreatic pseudocysts, Advances in endoscopic management . Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2016;45:9-27. Pancreas cystic lesion, looking like pseudocyst, but SPT

slide.title: Techniques for pseudocyst drainage
slide.notes: Techniques for pseudodrainage include surgical, percutaneous, endoscopic and hybrid approaches. With the advent of newer and more advanced endoscopic tools and expertise, and an associated reduction in health care costs, minimally invasive endoscopic drainage has become the preferable approach.3 EUS-guided approach appeared to be advantageous in drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts located adjacent to the stomach or duodenum. In patients with unfavorable anatomy, surgical cystogastrostomy or percutaneous drainage could be considered.
slide.notesNormalized: techniques for pseudodrainage include surgical, percutaneous, endoscopic and hybrid approaches. with the advent of newer and more advanced endoscopic tools and expertise, and an associated reduction in health care costs, minimally invasive endoscopic drainage has become the preferable approach.3 eus-guided approach appeared to be advantageous in drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts located adjacent to the stomach or duodenum. in patients with unfavorable anatomy, surgical cystogastrostomy or percutaneous drainage could be considered.
slide.notesHtml: Techniques for pseudodrainage include surgical, percutaneous, endoscopic and hybrid approaches. With the advent of newer and more advanced endoscopic tools and expertise, and an associated reduction in health care costs, minimally invasive endoscopic drainage has become the preferable approach.3 EUS-guided approach appeared to be advantageous in drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts located adjacent to the stomach or duodenum. In patients with unfavorable anatomy, surgical cystogastrostomy or percutaneous drainage could be considered.
slide.text:
Techniques for pseudocyst drainage Surgical; open or laparoscopic drainage Percutaneous irrigation or drainage Endoscopic drainage Hybrid; percutaneous and endoscopic drainage
Ge PS, et al. Pancreatic pseudocysts, Advances in endoscopic management . Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2016;45:9-27 . Tyberg A, et al. Management of pancreatic fluid collections: A comprehensive review of the literature. World J Gastroenterol 2016; 22: 2256-70. Teoh AYB, et al Systematic review comparing endoscopic, percutaneous and surgical pancreatic pseudocyst drainage. World J Gastroenterol 2016; 8: 310-8.

slide.title: Endoscopic techniques
slide.notes: Endoscopic drainage can be performed using either a transmural or transpapillary technique. Non–EUS-guided transmural drainage requires close proximity of the pseudocyst to the gastrointestinal lumen, as well as endoscopic localization in the form of a visible luminal bulge (Fig. 2). Nowadays EUS is increasingly used to guide transmural drainage. Two randomized trials that compared EUS-guided PPC drainage and conventional endoscopy-guided PPC drainage, demonstrated that EUS-guided drainage is superior to conventional endoscopy-guided drainage in terms of technical success and occurrence of procedure-related adverse events.
slide.notesNormalized: endoscopic drainage can be performed using either a transmural or transpapillary technique. non–eus-guided transmural drainage requires close proximity of the pseudocyst to the gastrointestinal lumen, as well as endoscopic localization in the form of a visible luminal bulge (fig. 2). nowadays eus is increasingly used to guide transmural drainage. two randomized trials that compared eus-guided ppc drainage and conventional endoscopy-guided ppc drainage, demonstrated that eus-guided drainage is superior to conventional endoscopy-guided drainage in terms of technical success and occurrence of procedure-related adverse events.
slide.notesHtml: Endoscopic drainage can be performed using either a transmural or transpapillary technique. Non–EUS-guided transmural drainage requires close proximity of the pseudocyst to the gastrointestinal lumen, as well as endoscopic localization in the form of a visible luminal bulge (Fig. 2). Nowadays EUS is increasingly used to guide transmural drainage. Two randomized trials that compared EUS-guided PPC drainage and conventional endoscopy-guided PPC drainage, demonstrated that EUS-guided drainage is superior to conventional endoscopy-guided drainage in terms of technical success and occurrence of procedure-related adverse events.
slide.text:
Endoscopic techniques Transmural drainage with/without EUS guidance Transpapillary drainage
Ge PS, et al. Pancreatic pseudocysts, Advances in endoscopic management . Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2016;45:9-27 . Tyberg A, et al. Management of pancreatic fluid collections: A comprehensive review of the literature. World J Gastroenterol 2016; 22: 2256-70. Teoh AYB, et al Systematic review comparing endoscopic, percutaneous and surgical pancreatic pseudocyst drainage. World J Gastroenterol 2016; 8: 310-8.

slide.title: Endoscopic techniques
slide.notes: Endoscopic transpapillary drainage with placement of a pancreatic duct stent is typically reserved for pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm and with communication to the main pancreatic duct. A combined transmural and transpapillary approach is not typically required for successful resolution of most pancreatic pseudocysts. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with PD exploration should be performed concurrent to transmural pseudocyst drainage. PD disruption is associated with an increased severity of pancreatitis, an increased risk of recurrent attacks of pancreatitis and long-term complications, and a decreased rate of peudocyst resolution after drainage. Any PD disruption should be bridged with endoscopic stenting.
slide.notesNormalized: endoscopic transpapillary drainage with placement of a pancreatic duct stent is typically reserved for pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm and with communication to the main pancreatic duct. a combined transmural and transpapillary approach is not typically required for successful resolution of most pancreatic pseudocysts. endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with pd exploration should be performed concurrent to transmural pseudocyst drainage. pd disruption is associated with an increased severity of pancreatitis, an increased risk of recurrent attacks of pancreatitis and long-term complications, and a decreased rate of peudocyst resolution after drainage. any pd disruption should be bridged with endoscopic stenting.
slide.notesHtml: Endoscopic transpapillary drainage with placement of a pancreatic duct stent is typically reserved for pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm and with communication to the main pancreatic duct. A combined transmural and transpapillary approach is not typically required for successful resolution of most pancreatic pseudocysts. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with PD exploration should be performed concurrent to transmural pseudocyst drainage. PD disruption is associated with an increased severity of pancreatitis, an increased risk of recurrent attacks of pancreatitis and long-term complications, and a decreased rate of peudocyst resolution after drainage. Any PD disruption should be bridged with endoscopic stenting.

Endoscopic techniques Transmural drainage with/without EUS guidance Transpapillary drainage
Ge PS, et al. Pancreatic pseudocysts, Advances in endoscopic management . Gastroenterol Clin North Am 2016;45:9-27 . Tyberg A, et al. Management of pancreatic fluid collections: A comprehensive review of the literature. World J Gastroenterol 2016; 22: 2256-70. slide.title: Stent Placement, Plastic vs. Metal
slide.notes: A variety of different stents are available for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage, including plastic pigtail stents, covered self-expanding metal stents (SEMS), and new LAMS. Based on the currently available literature, the standard of practice in endoscopic drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts remains the placement of multiple double pigtail plastic stents, with or without a fully covered SEMS. For the comprehension of the benefit of plastic stents and SEMS individually, three cases will be presented.
slide.notesNormalized: a variety of different stents are available for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage, including plastic pigtail stents, covered self-expanding metal stents (sems), and new lams. based on the currently available literature, the standard of practice in endoscopic drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts remains the placement of multiple double pigtail plastic stents, with or without a fully covered sems. for the comprehension of the benefit of plastic stents and sems individually, three cases will be presented.
slide.notesHtml:
A variety of different stents are available for pancreatic pseudocyst drainage, including plastic pigtail stents, covered self-expanding metal stents (SEMS), and new LAMS.

Based on the currently available literature, the standard of practice in endoscopic drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts remains the placement of multiple double pigtail plastic stents, with or without a fully covered SEMS. For the comprehension of the benefit of plastic stents and SEMS individually, three cases will be presented.
slide.text:
Stent Placement, Plastic vs. Metal Plastic pigtail stents Metal stents - Classic covered self-expanding metal stents - New lumen-apposing metal stents
Which stent is better ?

slide.title: Case, plastic stent
slide.notes: First case with a plastic stent for peudocyst drainage. A 44-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy due to 3 cm neuroendocrine tumor in tail. Six weeks after, 6 cm sized pseudocyst was developed in the tail.
slide.notesNormalized: first case with a plastic stent for peudocyst drainage. a 44-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy due to 3 cm neuroendocrine tumor in tail. six weeks after, 6 cm sized pseudocyst was developed in the tail.
slide.notesHtml: First case with a plastic stent for peudocyst drainage. A 44-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy due to 3 cm neuroendocrine tumor in tail. Six weeks after, 6 cm sized pseudocyst was developed in the tail.
slide.text:
Case, plastic stent 44 y, male Pseudocyst after distal pancreatectomy for NET
3cm NET in tail After distal pancreatectomy 6 weeks after

slide.title: Case, plastic stent
slide.notes: When he presented with abdominal pain, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided transmural drainage of the pancreatic pseudocyst was performed, and a 7-Fr, 7-cm double-pigtail plastic stent was placed in the cavity. Non viscous fluid gushed out actively through the stent and fistula.
slide.notesNormalized: when he presented with abdominal pain, endoscopic ultrasound (eus)-guided transmural drainage of the pancreatic pseudocyst was performed, and a 7-fr, 7-cm double-pigtail plastic stent was placed in the cavity. non viscous fluid gushed out actively through the stent and fistula.
slide.notesHtml: When he presented with abdominal pain, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided transmural drainage of the pancreatic pseudocyst was performed, and a 7-Fr, 7-cm double-pigtail plastic stent was placed in the cavity. Non viscous fluid gushed out actively through the stent and fistula.
slide.text: Case, plastic stent 44 y, male EUS-guided transmural drainage with a plastic stent

slide.title: Case, plastic stent
slide.notes: Three months after pseudocyst drainage, his CT showed complete resolution of the pseudocyst. The stent was removed. Abdominal CT after 6 months showed no evidence of pseudocyst.
slide.notesNormalized: three months after pseudocyst drainage, his ct showed complete resolution of the pseudocyst. the stent was removed. abdominal ct after 6 months showed no evidence of pseudocyst.
slide.notesHtml: Three months after pseudocyst drainage, his CT showed complete resolution of the pseudocyst. The stent was removed. Abdominal CT after 6 months showed no evidence of pseudocyst.
slide.text:
Case, plastic stent 44 y, male Resolution and removal of the stent
3 months after 6 months after

slide.title: Single-step vs. 2-step management
slide.notes: In the first case, EUS-guided drainage for 6 cm sized non viscous pseudocyst was performed with a single-step procedure using a double pigtailed plastic stent only. However, according to Yuan’s study, the 2-step procedure with a double-pigtail stent plus nasocystic drain for 72 hours resulted in a lower infection complication rate and an average of less days of hospitalization compared with single-step approach with only double-pigtail stent insertion for drainage of giant pseudocysts. Hence, the preferred treatment for drainage of huge (larger than 10 cm in in diameter) pancreatic pseudocysts is EUS insertion of 2 double-pigtail stents combined with insertion of a nasocystic external drain.
slide.notesNormalized: in the first case, eus-guided drainage for 6 cm sized non viscous pseudocyst was performed with a single-step procedure using a double pigtailed plastic stent only. however, according to yuan’s study, the 2-step procedure with a double-pigtail stent plus nasocystic drain for 72 hours resulted in a lower infection complication rate and an average of less days of hospitalization compared with single-step approach with only double-pigtail stent insertion for drainage of giant pseudocysts. hence, the preferred treatment for drainage of huge (larger than 10 cm in in diameter) pancreatic pseudocysts is eus insertion of 2 double-pigtail stents combined with insertion of a nasocystic external drain.
slide.notesHtml: In the first case, EUS-guided drainage for 6 cm sized non viscous pseudocyst was performed with a single-step procedure using a double pigtailed plastic stent only. However, according to Yuan’s study, the 2-step procedure with a double-pigtail stent plus nasocystic drain for 72 hours resulted in a lower infection complication rate and an average of less days of hospitalization compared with single-step approach with only double-pigtail stent insertion for drainage of giant pseudocysts. Hence, the preferred treatment for drainage of huge (larger than 10 cm in in diameter) pancreatic pseudocysts is EUS insertion of 2 double-pigtail stents combined with insertion of a nasocystic external drain.
slide.text: A double-pigtail stent vs. double-pigtail stent plus nasocystic drain Single-step vs. 2-step management Infection rate, 56.5% In hospital, 22.9 days Disappearance time, 14.1 w Single-step 2-step Infection rate, 20.8% In hospital, 10.3 days Disappearance time, 11.7 w Pancreas 2015; 44; 570-3 Nasocystic drain, more benefit Recurrent rate 5.3% Recurrent rate, 9.5% P < 0.05 P > 0.05

slide.title: Case, metal stent (LAMS)
slide.notes: Second case with a metal stent for the drainage of infected pseudocyst, A 47-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy for the treatment of huge serous cystadenoma in tail. 6 months after surgery, he presented with abdominal pain and fever. His abdominal CT and EUS showed a 11 cm sized pseudocyst with air suggesting infection.
slide.notesNormalized: second case with a metal stent for the drainage of infected pseudocyst, a 47-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy for the treatment of huge serous cystadenoma in tail. 6 months after surgery, he presented with abdominal pain and fever. his abdominal ct and eus showed a 11 cm sized pseudocyst with air suggesting infection.
slide.notesHtml: Second case with a metal stent for the drainage of infected pseudocyst, A 47-year old man underwent distal pancreatectomy for the treatment of huge serous cystadenoma in tail. 6 months after surgery, he presented with abdominal pain and fever. His abdominal CT and EUS showed a 11 cm sized pseudocyst with air suggesting infection.
slide.text: Case, metal stent (LAMS) 47y M Infected pseudocyst after distal pancreatectomy for cystic neoplasm

slide.title: Lumen Apposition Metal Stent (LAMS)
slide.notes: Recently, new full covered SEMS for lumen apposition with a conventional stent delivery system was developed in south Korea by Dr Moon group. They reported that EUS-guided transgastric drainage of pancreatic fluid collection and gall bladder using a LAMS was a technically feasible endoscopic approach and provided a route for interventional endoscopic procedures.
slide.notesNormalized: recently, new full covered sems for lumen apposition with a conventional stent delivery system was developed in south korea by dr moon group. they reported that eus-guided transgastric drainage of pancreatic fluid collection and gall bladder using a lams was a technically feasible endoscopic approach and provided a route for interventional endoscopic procedures.
slide.notesHtml: Recently, new full covered SEMS for lumen apposition with a conventional stent delivery system was developed in south Korea by Dr Moon group. They reported that EUS-guided transgastric drainage of pancreatic fluid collection and gall bladder using a LAMS was a technically feasible endoscopic approach and provided a route for interventional endoscopic procedures.
slide.text: Lumen Apposition Metal Stent (LAMS) “A new, fully covered self-expandable metal stent for lumen apposition, delivered by using a conventional delivery system, was feasible for EUS-guided pancreatic pseudocyst drainage.” Moon et al, GIE, 2014; 79: 990-5

slide.title: Case, metal stent (LAMS)
slide.notes: Therefore, he underwent EUS-guided pseudocyst drainage with a LAMS. After LAMS deployment, thick pus gushed out actively and he recovered uneventfully.
slide.notesNormalized: therefore, he underwent eus-guided pseudocyst drainage with a lams. after lams deployment, thick pus gushed out actively and he recovered uneventfully.

slide.text: Case, metal stent (LAMS) 47y M Transmural drainage with LAMS

slide.title: Case, metal stent (classic SEMS)
slide.notes: Third case with classic SEMS, A 56-year-old man with acute necrotising pancreatitis complicated by infected pancreatic necrosis. There is a heterogeneous, acute necrotic collection (ANC) in the pancreatic and peripancreatic area (white arrows pointing at the borders of the ANC) with presence of gas bubbles (white arrowheads), usually a pathognomonic sign of infection of the necrosis (infected necrosis).
slide.notesNormalized: third case with classic sems, a 56-year-old man with acute necrotising pancreatitis complicated by infected pancreatic necrosis. there is a heterogeneous, acute necrotic collection (anc) in the pancreatic and peripancreatic area (white arrows pointing at the borders of the anc) with presence of gas bubbles (white arrowheads), usually a pathognomonic sign of infection of the necrosis (infected necrosis).
slide.notesHtml: Third case with classic SEMS, A 56-year-old man with acute necrotising pancreatitis complicated by infected pancreatic necrosis. There is a heterogeneous, acute necrotic collection (ANC) in the pancreatic and peripancreatic area (white arrows pointing at the borders of the ANC) with presence of gas bubbles (white arrowheads), usually a pathognomonic sign of infection of the necrosis (infected necrosis).
slide.text: Case, metal stent (classic SEMS) 56y M, acute necrotizing pancreatitis By Dr. Kim TH from WK university

slide.title: Case, metal stent (classic SEMS)
slide.notes: This movie showed that the infected walled-off necrosis was punctured with 19 gauze needle and successful drainage was performed with a SEMS deployment.

slide.title: Case, metal stent (classic SEMS)
slide.notes: 48 days after drainage, his abdominal CT showed complete resolution of the infected walled off necrosis.
slide.notesNormalized: 48 days after drainage, his abdominal ct showed complete resolution of the infected walled off necrosis.
slide.notesHtml: 48 days after drainage, his abdominal CT showed complete resolution of the infected walled off necrosis.

slide.title: Case, metal stent (classic SEMS)
slide.notes: After resolution of the infected walled off necrosis, Dr Kim removed the SEMS with a rat tooth forceps. Four months after removal of the stent, gastroscopy showed complete healing of the fistula tract.

slide.title: Stent Placement, Plastic vs. Metal
slide.notes: Before we conclude which stent is better between plastic and metal stent. Some study results will be discussed further.
slide.notesNormalized: before we conclude which stent is better between plastic and metal stent. some study results will be discussed further.
slide.notesHtml: Before we conclude which stent is better between plastic and metal stent. Some study results will be discussed further.
slide.text: Stent Placement, Plastic vs. Metal Which stent is better ?

slide.title: Sharaiha et al, GIE 2015;82:822-7.
slide.notes: Despite the advantage of self-expanding metal stents in draining pancreatic fluid collections, no clinical trials exist to demonstrate that metal stents are superior to plastic stents with regard to effectiveness, adverse events, and pseudocyst recurrence rate. However, recently, Sharaiha et al demonstrated that EUS-guided drainage by using FCSEMSs improves clinical outcomes and lowers adverse event rates compared with those drained with double pigtailed plastic stents.
slide.notesNormalized: despite the advantage of self-expanding metal stents in draining pancreatic fluid collections, no clinical trials exist to demonstrate that metal stents are superior to plastic stents with regard to effectiveness, adverse events, and pseudocyst recurrence rate. however, recently, sharaiha et al demonstrated that eus-guided drainage by using fcsemss improves clinical outcomes and lowers adverse event rates compared with those drained with double pigtailed plastic stents.
slide.notesHtml:
Despite the advantage of self-expanding metal stents in draining pancreatic fluid collections, no clinical trials exist to demonstrate that metal stents are superior to plastic stents with regard to effectiveness, adverse events, and pseudocyst recurrence rate. However, recently, Sharaiha et al demonstrated that EUS-guided drainage by using FCSEMSs improves clinical outcomes and lowers

adverse event rates compared with those drained with double pigtailed plastic stents.
slide.text: Conclusion: In patients with PPs, EUS-guided drainage by using FCSEMSs improves clinical outcomes & lowers adverse event compared with those drained with DP plastic stents. Sharaiha et al, GIE 2015;82:822-7.

slide.title: Short-term Placement of SEMS (3 weeks)
slide.notes: The appropriate period for stent removal is not known. Recent study by India and Hong Kong showed that pancreatic ductal leak or disconnection was an independent factor affecting pseudocyst resolution at 3 weeks. Therefore, short-term placement of FCSEMSs with pancreatic ductal stenting in selected patients appears safe and effective for the treatment of pseudocysts.
slide.notesNormalized: the appropriate period for stent removal is not known. recent study by india and hong kong showed that pancreatic ductal leak or disconnection was an independent factor affecting pseudocyst resolution at 3 weeks. therefore, short-term placement of fcsemss with pancreatic ductal stenting in selected patients appears safe and effective for the treatment of pseudocysts.
slide.notesHtml:
The appropriate period for stent removal is not known. Recent study by India and Hong Kong showed that pancreatic

ductal leak or disconnection was an independent factor affecting pseudocyst resolution at 3 weeks. Therefore, short-term placement of FCSEMSs with pancreatic ductal stenting in selected patients appears safe and effective for the treatment of pseudocysts.
slide.text: Short-term Placement of SEMS (3 weeks) Gastrointest Endosc 2015;82:650-7. “ Short-term placement of FCSEMSs with pancreatic ductal stenting in selected patients appears safe and effective for the treatment of pseudocysts”

slide.title: Additional Benefit of SEMS
slide.notes: Additional benefit of SEMS is that direct endoscopic necrosectomy can be carried out through the SEMS in most of cases.
slide.notesNormalized: additional benefit of sems is that direct endoscopic necrosectomy can be carried out through the sems in most of cases.
slide.notesHtml: Additional benefit of SEMS is that direct endoscopic necrosectomy can be carried out through the SEMS in most of cases.
slide.text: Additional Benefit of SEMS Direct endoscopic necrosectomy can be carried out in most of cases. GIE 2015;82:1039-46.

slide.title: Survey on EUS-guided drainage, Plastic vs. Metal (Asian EUS group)
slide.titleNormalized: survey on eus-guided drainage, plastic vs. metal (asian eus group)
slide.notes: Is it time to embrace SEMSs for PPC management instead of plastic stents? Before making final conclusions, we must consider the Survey results on EUS-guided drainage by Asian EUS group. They reported that metallic stents were used by only 10.5% of the respondents.
slide.notesNormalized: is it time to embrace semss for ppc management instead of plastic stents? before making final conclusions, we must consider the survey results on eus-guided drainage by asian eus group. they reported that metallic stents were used by only 10.5% of the respondents.
slide.notesHtml: Is it time to embrace SEMSs for PPC management instead of plastic stents? Before making final conclusions, we must consider the Survey results on EUS-guided drainage by Asian EUS group. They reported that metallic stents were used by only 10.5% of the respondents.
slide.text: Metallic stents were used by 10.5% of the respondents. Transcystic catheters were employed by 26.3 %. Those who were more experienced in the procedure Tended to use the cystotome more frequently (P=0.02) Removed the stents in less than 3 months after insertion Survey on EUS-guided drainage, Plastic vs. Metal (Asian EUS group) Endoscopy International Open 2015; 03: E130–E133 Song TJ, Lee SS. Clinical Endosc 2014;47:222-6.

slide.title: Digestive endoscopy 2016; in express
slide.notes: Yes, plastic stents have a strong benefit that mean hospital costs are significantly lower for pseudocysts using plastic stents compared with SEMS including LAMS.
slide.notesNormalized: yes, plastic stents have a strong benefit that mean hospital costs are significantly lower for pseudocysts using plastic stents compared with sems including lams.
slide.notesHtml: Yes, plastic stents have a strong benefit that mean hospital costs are significantly lower for pseudocysts using plastic stents compared with SEMS including LAMS.
slide.text: Digestive endoscopy 2016; in express “Cost analysis”

slide.title: Is it time to embrace SEMS for PPC management?
slide.titleNormalized: is it time to embrace sems for ppc management?
slide.notes: Coming back to the question, is it time to embrace SEMSs for PPC management? The functional success rate with plastic stents is in excess of 90%, and it will be difficult for SEMSs to significantly improve on this. The areas where SEMSs may potentially score are ease of placement, fewer early and late infectious adverse events, and better long-term results including lower recurrence rates. Early removal of the FCSEMS may also be possible in patients without ductal communications, thus reducing probability of delayed adverse events. Cost-effectiveness of short-term FCSEMS placement versus longer-term plastic stent placement will need to be assessed if FCSEMSs show advantages over plastic stents. SEMSs are an exciting addition to the management of symptomatic pseudocyst, but it is too early to discard plastic stents because better evidence is needed.
slide.notesNormalized: coming back to the question, is it time to embrace semss for ppc management? the functional success rate with plastic stents is in excess of 90%, and it will be difficult for semss to significantly improve on this. the areas where semss may potentially score are ease of placement, fewer early and late infectious adverse events, and better long-term results including lower recurrence rates. early removal of the fcsems may also be possible in patients without ductal communications, thus reducing probability of delayed adverse events. cost-effectiveness of short-term fcsems placement versus longer-term plastic stent placement will need to be assessed if fcsemss show advantages over plastic stents. semss are an exciting addition to the management of symptomatic pseudocyst, but it is too early to discard plastic stents because better evidence is needed.
slide.notesHtml:
Coming back to the question, is it time to embrace SEMSs for PPC management? The functional success rate with plastic stents is in excess of 90%, and it will be difficult for SEMSs to significantly

improve on this. The areas where SEMSs may potentially score are ease of placement, fewer early and late infectious adverse events, and better long-term results including lower recurrence rates. Early removal of the FCSEMS may also be possible in patients without ductal communications, thus reducing probability of delayed adverse events. Cost-effectiveness of short-term FCSEMS placement versus

longer-term plastic stent placement will need to be assessed if FCSEMSs show advantages over plastic stents. SEMSs are an exciting addition to the management of symptomatic pseudocyst, but it is too early to discard plastic stents because better evidence is needed.
slide.text: Is it time to embrace SEMS for PPC management? Functional Success > 90% Inexpensive Plastic stent SEMS Functional success > 90% Expensive GIE 2015; 10; 1042-6. Song TJ, Lee SS. Clinical Endosc 2014;47:222-6. Inconclusive! Better evidence is needed Fewer early and late infection Lower recurrence rates Early removal Shorter procedure time, 15 m Frequent early and late infection higher recurrence rates late removal Longer procedure time, 29.5m

slide.title: Conclusion: Plastic vs. Metal Stent for Pseudocyst Drainage
slide.titleNormalized: conclusion: plastic vs. metal stent for pseudocyst drainage
slide.notes: In conclusion, both plastic stents and metal stents can be used individually according to the feature of the pseudocysts. For the drainage of the pseudocyst with small size and no thick debris, single step double pigtailed plastic stent will be enough. However, for the drainage of the pseudocyst with thick debris, SEMS including LAMS are more beneficial option.
slide.notesNormalized: in conclusion, both plastic stents and metal stents can be used individually according to the feature of the pseudocysts. for the drainage of the pseudocyst with small size and no thick debris, single step double pigtailed plastic stent will be enough. however, for the drainage of the pseudocyst with thick debris, sems including lams are more beneficial option.
slide.notesHtml: In conclusion, both plastic stents and metal stents can be used individually according to the feature of the pseudocysts. For the drainage of the pseudocyst with small size and no thick debris, single step double pigtailed plastic stent will be enough. However, for the drainage of the pseudocyst with thick debris, SEMS including LAMS are more beneficial option.
slide.text: Conclusion: Plastic vs. Metal Stent for Pseudocyst Drainage
